title: 104_s1241
content: The Public Broadcasting Financial Independence and Family Viewing Act of 1995 establishes guidelines for family-friendly programming, prohibits the use of federal funds for indecent or nudity-inclusive programs, and emphasizes the importance of providing educational and entertaining content suitable for family viewing. SEC. 5. SPECTRUM FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will allow public broadcast license holders to use their spectrum for ancillary services, ensuring proceeds benefit public broadcasting and fees for non-broadcasting use are at market rates. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will allow public broadcast license holders to provide non-public broadcast programming for a fee between 1 a.m. and 6 a.m., with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting. Commercially sponsored programming is permitted as long as existing public broadcasting commitments are maintained and fees are at market rates. SEC. 7. ENHANCED UNDERWRITING. Amendments to title 47 allow for the promotion of products or services through calls to action or price information. SEC. 8. SATELLITE, COMMON CARRIER AND OTHER FORMS OF PROGRAM DISTRIBUTION. Public Broadcasting programs can be distributed via various technologies for a fee, with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting. SEC. 9. FREQUENCY EXCHANGE. The Commission can approve frequency exchanges between public and commercial broadcasters if the proceeds benefit the national public broadcasting system. SEC. 10. ANCILLARY INCOME. Agreements for programming should ensure that public broadcasting benefits from the sale of related products. SEC. 11. GAO REVIEW. The General Accounting Office will review the operations of public broadcasting entities and make recommendations for improvement. They will also study the feasibility of merging public broadcasting with international broadcasting operations. Additionally, educational rates will be addressed. Public broadcast licensees qualify for educational telecommunications service rates for providing public broadcasting.
